paragraphs.context: Healthy vaginal discharge is a normal and natural occurrence that helps keep the vagina clean and lubricated. It varies in consistency, colour, and odor throughout the menstrual cycle. Generally, healthy vaginal discharge can range from clear to white or slightly yellowish in colour. It is usually odourless or has a mild, musky scent. The consistency can be thin and watery or thicker and sticky, depending on the stage of the menstrual cycle. On the other hand, unhealthy vaginal discharge may indicate an underlying issue or infection. Signs of unhealthy discharge include unusual colour: discharge that is green, grey, or has a strong yellow hue may indicate an infection or other health concern. Unpleasant odour: foul-smelling discharge, especially if it is accompanied by itching, irritation, or discomfort, could be a sign of an infection, such as bacterial vaginosis or a sexually transmitted infection (sti). Abnormal consistency: if the discharge becomes clumpy, cottage cheese-like, frothy, or has an unusual texture, it could be a sign of a yeast infection or another type of infection. Itching, irritation, or burning: discharge accompanied by persistent itching, redness, or a burning sensation may indicate an infection or allergic reaction. If you notice any significant changes in your vaginal discharge that are accompanied by other symptoms or concerns, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider. They can evaluate your symptoms, perform necessary tests, and provide appropriate treatment if needed. The colour of menstrual blood can vary from person to person and can change throughout the duration of the menstrual cycle. Typically, menstrual blood is shades of red, ranging from bright red to dark red. However, it is common for the colour to be slightly different at the beginning and end of the period. At the start of the menstrual cycle, the bleeding may be brighter red and slightly heavier. As the period progresses, the blood may become darker and may have a brownish or even blackish tinge. This is because the blood may take some time to exit the body and may be exposed to oxygen, which can cause it to change in colour. The colour of menstrual blood can also be influenced by factors such as the flow rate, hormonal changes, and the presence of blood clots. If you notice any significant changes in the colour of your menstrual blood or have concerns about your menstrual health, it's always a good idea to consult with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and guidance. A normal period typically lasts between three to seven days. However, it's important to note that menstrual cycles can vary from person to person, and what is considered "normal" can differ for everyone. Some people may have shorter or longer periods, ranging from two to eight days. It's also common for the length and characteristics of periods to change over time due to factors such as age, hormonal changes, stress, and underlying health conditions. If you have concerns about the duration or pattern of your menstrual period, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider.

paragraphs.context: Menstruation, commonly called periods occurs only in females. Its a regular shedding of the inner layer (endometrium layer) of the uterus. The menstrual cycle is regulated by hormones in the body. It is called a menstrual cycle because, after every 28 days, there is uterine bleeding that comes out through the vagina. The date of menstrual bleeding (bleeding through the vagina) is noted in the calendar as day 1 (first day of the cycle) and the bleed continues for 3-5 days. Then the release of the egg (ovum) from the ovary on the 14th day of the cycle and the next menstrual bleeding occurs after 2830 days. It is always good to keep a diary or note of the period dates, so a girl can be prepared. For her next period, and it is also helpful in making future plans. There are also lots of mobile applications or online websites to calculate or make notes of it. If the menstrual bleeding started on 10th january (day 1), then the ovulation date will be 28th january (14 days after) and the next menstrual bleed will occur around 7th february (28th day). It is the time period of the menstrual cycle during which, if unprotected sexual intercourse is done, there is a higher chance of fertilisation of the ovum with sperm leading to pregnancy. Ovulation occurs on the 14th day and lasts for 3 days. Sperm has a life span of 72 hours (3 days). So, the fertile period ranges from the 10th day until the 17th day of the menstrual cycle. A couple can use this knowledge to conceive a baby. Use of this knowledge for contraception is not advisable due to the higher failure rate. Menstruation usually starts by the age of 10 to 15 years (called menarche). If after 16 years also your menstruation doesnt start, then you need to consult a doctor. There may be underlying causes like an imperforate hymen, an absent or anomalous uterus, a hormonal disorder, etc. The menstrual cycle (periods) occurs due to hormonal changes. As soon as the bleeding from the uterus stops, the body starts preparing for pregnancy with the hope that in the next cycle, pregnancy will occur (by fertilisation with sperm) and the thickness of the inner layer of the uterus will increase. When the ovum doesnt meet sperm during the fertile period, the inner thickened lining (endometrium) of the uterus starts shedding and comes out in the form of blood through the vagina.

paragraphs.context: Informally, a crush is a sort of attraction for a person, whether for looks, intelligence, skills, or anything else. When you have a crush on someone, it means that you find that person very attractive or that you have a strong desire for that person. Eventually, it may grow into love, or it may diminish in time. People often perceive a crush as an infatuation. Idolize refers to the act of regarding someone with great admiration, reverence, or devotion. When you idolize someone, you place them on a pedestal and perceive them as an ideal or perfect figure. It involves looking up to someone with a high degree of admiration, often for their qualities, achievements, or perceived greatness. Idolizing someone can involve strong emotional attachment and a tendency to overlook or minimize their flaws or shortcomings. It is important to maintain a balanced perspective when idolizing someone and to recognize their humanity, acknowledging that no one is perfect. The differences between crush and idolise are crushes are usually temporary infatuations or attractions, idolizing someone involves a more intense and long-lasting admiration, often regarding them as an ideal or perfect figure. Having a crush on someone or idolizing them can be okay as long as it is done in a healthy and balanced manner. It is natural to feel attracted to someone's qualities, talents, or achievements and to admire them. However, it's important to remember that everyone is human and has flaws. It's crucial to maintain realistic expectations and avoid putting someone on a pedestal or idealizing them to an unrealistic extent. It's also important to respect the boundaries and consent of the person you have a crush on or idolize, and to remember that they are entitled to their own autonomy and personal space. Healthy admiration and attraction should not interfere with your own self-worth or lead to unhealthy or obsessive behaviours.

paragraphs.context: The groin is the area of the body located between the abdomen and the thigh on either side of the pubic bone. It is also referred to as the inguinal region. The groin area is where the lower abdomen meets the upper inner thigh. It contains various structures, including muscles, lymph nodes, blood vessels, and the inguinal canal. The groin area is commonly associated with the hip joints and is susceptible to strains or injuries, particularly in physically active individuals. Itching in the groin area can be a common occurrence and may be caused by various factors. It can be considered normal if it is mild and temporary. However, persistent, or intense itching in the groin area may indicate an underlying issue that requires attention. Some possible causes of itching in the groin area include fungal infections: conditions such as jock itch (tinea cruris) caused by a fungal infection can lead to itching in the groin region. Contact dermatitis: exposure to irritants or allergens in soaps, detergents, fabrics, or personal care products can cause itching and skin irritation in the groin area. Moisture and friction: excessive moisture, sweat, and friction in the groin area, particularly in warm or humid environments, can lead to itching and skin irritation. Skin conditions: certain skin conditions like eczema or psoriasis can manifest with itching in the groin area. Hygiene practices: poor hygiene, infrequent bathing, or using harsh soaps can contribute to itching and discomfort in the groin region. If you are experiencing persistent or severe itching in the groin area, it is advisable to consult with a healthcare provider or dermatologist. They can assess your specific situation, provide an accurate diagnosis, and recommend appropriate treatment options to relieve the itching and address any underlying causes. Ways to deal with groyne fungal infection / itchy groyne: 1. Wear loose underwear, if needed then can avoid underwear for few days. 2. Keep the groyne dry after the bath; make sure to wear only dry underwear. 3. If needed, remove pubic hair so the medications can be applied easily, and the groyne remains dry for a longer duration. 4. Dont share a towel, undergarment, or soap. 5. Use anti-fungal creams like clotrimazole, etc. 6. Feel free to consult a doctor.

paragraphs.context: Maintaining female genital hygiene is important for overall health and well-being. Here are some general guidelines for maintaining good female genital hygiene: cleanliness: wash the external genital area (vulva) with mild, unscented soap and warm water. Avoid using harsh soaps, douches, or perfumed products as they can disrupt the natural balance of the vagina and potentially cause irritation or infection. Remember to rinse thoroughly and pat dry with a clean towel. Proper wiping technique: when using the toilet, always wipe from front to back after urination or bowel movements. This helps prevent the spread of bacteria from the anal area to the vagina, reducing the risk of urinary tract infections and other infections. Menstrual hygiene: change sanitary pads, tampons, or menstrual cups regularly during menstruation to maintain cleanliness and prevent odor. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for proper use and disposal. Avoid tight-fitting underwear and clothing: wear breathable cotton underwear and loose-fitting clothing to allow air circulation and reduce moisture build-up, which can contribute to bacterial growth and infections. Practice safe sexual habits: if engaging in sexual activity, practice safe sex by using condoms and getting regular sexual health check-ups. It's also important to communicate openly with your partner about sexual health and any concerns. Regular check-ups: schedule regular visits with a healthcare provider for gynaecological exams, screenings, and to address any concerns or questions you may have regarding your genital health. Remember, every individual is unique, and it's important to listen to your body and seek medical advice if you experience any unusual symptoms, discomfort, or changes in your genital area. The vagina is a self-cleaning organ and has a delicate balance of natural bacteria and ph levels that help maintain its health. It is generally not recommended to put water or wash the inside of the vagina for the following reasons: disruption of natural balance: flushing water or using douches inside the vagina can disturb the natural balance of bacteria and ph levels, leading to an overgrowth of harmful bacteria or an imbalance known as bacterial vaginosis. This can result in vaginal odor, itching, irritation, or an increased risk of infections. Increased risk of infection: the vagina has a self-cleaning mechanism that naturally removes dead cells and discharge. Introducing water or other substances can disrupt this natural process and create an environment more susceptible to infections, including yeast infections or urinary tract infections. Irritation and drying: water, especially if it contains chemicals like soaps or shampoos, can irritate the sensitive vaginal tissues and cause dryness, itching, or discomfort. It's important to note that maintaining hygiene of the external genital area (vulva) is sufficient for daily cleanliness. Washing the vulva with mild, unscented soap and water is recommended, while avoiding harsh soaps or douches. If you have specific concerns about vaginal hygiene or notice any unusual symptoms, it's best to consult with a healthcare provider who can provide personalized advice and guidance.

paragraphs.context: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, both in developed and developing countries. It is more common in the 30s. Breast cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the breast cells. It occurs when abnormal cells in the breast grow and divide uncontrollably, forming a tumour. Breast cancer can affect both women and men, although it is more common in women. The risk factors for breast cancer are positive family history (genetics), prolonged exposure to endogenous oestrogen (such as early menarche, late menopause, and late age at first childbirth), exogenous hormones, radiation, alcohol use, overweight and obesity, and physical inactivity. Symptoms of breast cancer can vary, but common signs include a lump or thickening in the breast or underarm area, changes in breast size or shape, nipple changes or discharge, and skin changes like dimpling or redness. Early detection and treatment are crucial for improving the prognosis of breast cancer. Regular self-examination of the breasts and screening methods such as mammograms, clinical breast exams, and breast ultrasounds can help detect abnormalities or signs of cancer. If a suspicious lump or other symptoms are detected, further diagnostic tests such as a biopsy may be performed to confirm the presence of breast cancer. Treatment options for breast cancer depend on various factors, including the stage of cancer, its characteristics, and individual health considerations. Treatment may involve surgery (such as lumpectomy or mastectomy), radiation therapy, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, targeted therapy, or a combination of these approaches. To prevent breast cancer: maintain a healthy weight. Limit alcohol consumption. Stay physically active. Consider breastfeeding if possible. Avoid or limit hormone therapy. Know your family history and seek appropriate screenings. Perform regular breast self-exams. Attend recommended screenings. Remember, prevention strategies can help reduce the risk but do not guarantee complete prevention. Regular check-ups and discussions with healthcare professionals are important.

paragraphs.context: Circumcision is the removal of the foreskin (prepuce) of the penis through a surgical procedure. It is commonly practised in certain religions, like muslims and jews, during early childhood. It can also be done for some medical conditions like phimosis, hypospadias, etc. Research studies show that circumcision at an early age is protective against infections, penile cancer, and phimosis, and it doesnt affect sexual function or pleasure. However, it may have risks of surgical complications. The foreskin of the penis is non-retractable before 4-6 years of age; in certain cases, it may be up to 810 years. This is because the glans penis and foreskin are attached together by a layer that dissolves after a certain age. This is called physiological phimosis. Before this age, the foreskin of the penis shouldnt be retracted, as it can cause damage or injure the penis. There is no objective data to suggest that having a physiological phimosis leads to a pathological phimosis at a later stage. In adults, the prepuce is often retracted back during peeing (urination) or while cleaning the penis (while taking a bath). No, it wont intervene during the sexual intercourse. As during the sexual intercourse, prepuce is retracted back in an uncircumcised penis. Glans penis is the most sensitive part for the sexual stimulation. Direct stimulation over the glans penis in a fully lubricated vagina doesnt causes pain. In adults with an uncircumcised penis, the penis should be cleaned by retracting the prepuce (over the glans) with plain, simple water. As under the prepuce, a white colour material called smegma is deposited. Smegma is made up of dead tissues and mucin content. Smegma protects and lubricates the glans and inner lamella of the prepuce, facilitating erection, preputial eversion, and penetration during sexual intercourse. Smegma also contains lytic materials (such as lysozyme), which probably originate from the prostate, and seminal vesicles, which destroy bacterial cell walls. It also inhibits and destroys candida species (fungal microbes). If the smegma is not cleaned, then it may harden into smegma stones in men, as seen with extremely poor hygienic habits. If smegma is over-cleaned (very frequently cleaned), then a person can become susceptible to a penile candida infection. Therefore, the cleaning of smegma should be adequately done (maybe 2-3 times a week). The decision to circumcise the penis is a personal and cultural choice that varies across different regions and religions. It is not universally recommended or required. Some potential benefits include improved hygiene, reduced risk of certain infections (such as urinary tract infections and sexually transmitted infections like hiv), and a lower risk of penile cancer. However, these benefits are generally modest, and the overall impact on health is relatively small. On the other hand, circumcision is a surgical procedure that carries potential risks and complications, such as bleeding, infection, pain, and damage to the penis. It is advisable to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide information, guidance, and support in making an informed decision about circumcision.

paragraphs.context: There are three methods of contraception which are natural, temporary, and permanent methods. Natural method: 1. Abstinence from sex especially during the fertile period (10th to 17th days of the menstrual cycle) 2. Withdrawal or coitus interruptus (the male partner withdraws his penis from the vagina just before ejaculation) 3. Lactational amenorrhea is a method because ovulation is absent post the delivery of baby (maximum till first 6 months), if the baby is regularly breastfed. Temporary. Method: 1. Barrier methods like condoms (male condom), femidom (female condom), diaphragms, cervical caps, and vaults 2. Intra uterine devices (iuds) like copper-t 3. Injectables implants, 4. Injections (dmpa) 5. Oral contraceptive pills (ocp) which it also has many benefits and commonly used in the treatment of menstrual abnormalities. Permanent methods: 1. Vasectomy (vas deferens is cut in males). It is simpler and easier than tubectomy. 2. Tubectomy (fallopian tubes is cut in females). However, natural methods have higher chances of failure compared to the temporary and permanent methods. Vasectomy is a surgical procedure that involves cutting or blocking the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm from the testicles to the urethra. It is a form of permanent contraception for men, as it prevents sperm from reaching the semen ejaculated during sexual intercourse. After a vasectomy, men typically continue to produce sperm, but the sperm are absorbed by the body instead of being ejaculated. The testicles still produce hormones, including testosterone, so there is usually no change in sexual desire, performance, or the ability to achieve an erection. It's important to note that vasectomy is intended to be a permanent form of contraception, and while reversal procedures are available, they are not always successful. Therefore, it is recommended that men consider vasectomy as a permanent decision and carefully discuss the procedure with a healthcare professional to fully understand the implications and alternatives. Emergency contraception is not a regular method of birth control. Its only can be used after unprotected sexual intercourse, or if the birth control method failed (such as if a condom broke). 1. Copper iudwomen can have the copper-t iud inserted within five days of unprotected sex. 2. Emergency contraceptive pillswomen can take emergency contraceptive pills up to 3 to 5 days after unprotected sex. The sooner the pills are taken, the better they will work. They can be availed in the pharmacy or general stores in the name of ezy pill, i-pill, unwanted 72, plan-b, morning after, etc. Frequent use of emergency pills should be avoided as they can hamper menstrual cycles and cause hormonal imbalance. If there is a frequent need for emergency pills, then one needs to shift to other contraceptive methods like oral contraceptive pills (ocp), intrauterine devices (iucd) like copper t or injectable contraceptives. Please consult your doctor for contraceptive plan. If you or someone you know has been raped or sexually assaulted, you should report it to the police immediately.

paragraphs.context: The role of family is multi-faceted and essential in various aspects of life. Here are some key roles that families play: (1) nurturing and support: families provide emotional support, care, and nurturing to their members. They create a sense of belonging and offer a safe and loving environment where individuals can grow, develop, and thrive. (2) basic needs provision: families fulfil basic needs such as food, shelter, clothing, and healthcare. They ensure the well-being and physical sustenance of their members, promoting their health and stability. (3) socialization and values: families play a crucial role in socializing individuals and transmitting cultural values, beliefs, and norms. They teach social skills, moral values, and ethics, helping individuals navigate relationships and societal expectations. (4) education and learning: families contribute to the educational development of their members. They support learning, encourage intellectual curiosity, and provide guidance and resources for academic achievement. (5) identity formation: families significantly influence the development of individual identities. They shape a person's self-concept, self-esteem, and cultural or ethnic identity, providing a sense of heritage and belonging. (6) emotional stability: families offer emotional stability and a support system during times of challenge or crisis. They provide comfort, understanding, and encouragement, helping individuals cope with stress, grief, or trauma. (7) life skills and independence: families equip individuals with essential life skills necessary for independence and adulthood. They teach practical skills such as communication, problem-solving, decision-making, and financial management. (8) intergenerational connection: families foster intergenerational connections and promote continuity across generations. They provide a sense of lineage, family history, and connections to ancestors, passing down traditions and stories. (9) caregiving and aging support: families often assume caregiving roles, particularly for children and aging parents. They provide assistance, care, and support for family members in need, ensuring their well-being and quality of life. (10) social support network: families serve as a primary social support network, offering companionship, love, and companionship. They celebrate achievements, share joys, and provide a sense of community and belonging.

paragraphs.context: Sexual intercourse, or a sexual act (most people call it "sex), is usually performed between two mature adults with consent who are legally married or in a romantic relationship. It can be divided into coitus and non-coital sex. Coitus sex is the penile insertion into the females vagina. Non-coital sex is hugging, kissing (cheek, body, or on the mouth), touching, stimulating, and masturbation. Sexual intercourse is a natural biological function like respiration, eating and defecation. Healthy individuals have sex for reproduction or pleasure or for body need. You dont have to do anything if you dont want to have sex. Sex is something that is enjoyed only if it is done out of free will. Right now, it might seem quite strange to you, but later you might change your mind. Thats ok. Sex is a way of expressing ourselves and our feelings. It is not dirty or wicked. Sexual consent is an agreement to participate in sexual activity. It could be verbal (communicated) or in written form. Consent is never in the form of physical gestures, body signs, objects, indirect signals, actions, dress, etc. Consent is never implied based on past behaviour, activity, or dress. Valid consent is consent without any pressure or threat, without any influence of drugs or alcohol. Consent is always reversible at any point in time, and it must be very specific for every step or activity. Consent is required before every sexual act in life, even if you are a married couple or your partner is a sex worker. A sexual act without consent is always wrong and considered rape, which is a punishable crime. Everyone has the right to be in control of what they will and will not do with their bodies. Consent is a very important thing for a healthy, pleasurable relationship and consensual sexual behaviour with a partner. Consent should be actively communicated and recognised by their partners. If you have sex when you are ready for it with someone you care about and who cares about you, it feels good in your body and in your mind. But if you are scared, unwilling, or not ready for it, it may be the worst experience. Doing any sexual act because of pressure from someone else can have sex feel quite horrible. People describe sex as excited, warm, tingly, thrilled, pleasurable, gentle, loved, wanted, special, and happy. All societies accept sex between two lawfully married adults as safe and normal. Sex is a personal thing that is always done in private and with the consent of the partner. It should never be forced. A person can always freely choose when he or she wants to have sex. It also depends on cultural, religious, and personal moral values. Most people wait for the correct time when they are emotionally, mentally, and physically mature enough.

Look at the regions marked 'c' and 't' on the test card. 'c' indicates a control. This band must always appear because this is the comparison band. 't' indicates the test sample. 2. If only one pink or purple band appears in the region marked 'c', it means that the test is negative for pregnancy. 3. If two pink or purple bands appear, one in the region marked 'c' and the other in the region marked 't', it means that the test is positive for pregnancy 4. Pre-menstrual syndrome (pms) is a set of physical and psychological symptoms that start anywhere from a few days to two weeks before a woman gets her monthly period (menstruation). The causes of pms are not completely clear. But it is thought that hormonal fluctuations during a womans monthly cycle play a role. Many women experience breast tenderness and abdominal pain, for instance. Other symptoms include headaches, back pain and joint or muscle ache. Water retention, sleep problems or digestion problems, skin blemishes and food cravings may occur too. Women who have pms often feel exhausted, insecure, down, listless, irritable, or angry in the days leading up to their period. Some have problems concentrating and experience mood swings. They might feel like they are losing control over their body and emotions. Severe pms can really affect everyday life and relationships with friends, family, partners, and colleagues. paragraphs.context: Breast development, also known as breast budding, typically begins during puberty, which is a period of physical and hormonal changes that occur in girls. The exact age at which breast development starts can vary among individuals, but it commonly begins between the ages of 8 and 13. Breast development usually progresses through several stages over a span of a few years. Initially, small breast buds form beneath the nipple area, and gradually the breasts continue to grow and take on a more rounded shape. The size and pace of breast development can differ among individuals. Breast growth generally continues until the late teenage years or early twenties, but it varies for each person. The rate of growth and the final size of the breasts are influenced by factors such as genetics, hormones, and overall health. It's important to note that breast size is highly individual and can differ significantly among individuals. To measure your bra cup size, you will need a soft measuring tape and follow these steps: take the under bust measurement: stand straight and wrap the measuring tape snugly around your ribcage, just beneath your breasts. Ensure the tape is parallel to the ground and take note of the measurement in inches or centimetres. This will give you your band size. Measure the bust: keep the measuring tape around your back and bring it across the fullest part of your bust. Make sure the tape is not too tight or too loose and record the measurement. Calculate the difference: subtract your under bust measurement from your bust measurement. The difference between the two measurements will determine your cup size. Use a bra size chart or calculator to find your corresponding cup size based on the difference. For example, if your under bust measurement is 32 inches (81 cm) and your bust measurement is 36 inches (91 cm), the difference is 4 inches (10 cm), which typically corresponds to a d cup size.

paragraphs.context: Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the cervix, which is the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina. Various strains of the human papillomavirus (hpv), a sexually transmitted infection, play a role in causing most cervical cancers. Risk factors for cervical cancer are human papillomavirus (hpv), poor immune status (hiv), co-infection with other stds, tobacco smoking, young age at first baby birth, and multiple sexual partners. The symptoms of cervical cancer can vary, and in the early stages, there may be no noticeable signs. However, as the cancer progresses, the following symptoms may occur: abnormal vaginal bleeding: this includes bleeding between periods, after sexual intercourse, or after menopause. It may also involve unusually heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding. Unusual vaginal discharge: cervical cancer can cause a watery, bloody, or foul-smelling discharge that may be persistent. Pelvic pain: persistent pain in the pelvic area, including pain during sexual intercourse or pelvic examinations, can be a symptom of cervical cancer. Painful urination: some women with cervical cancer may experience pain or discomfort during urination. Back or leg pain: as the cancer progresses, it may spread to nearby tissues and organs, leading to back or leg pain. It's important to note that these symptoms can also be caused by conditions other than cervical cancer. If you experience any of these symptoms or have concerns, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation and appropriate testing. Regular cervical cancer screenings, such as pap smears and hpv tests, are essential for early detection and prevention. Prevention from cervical cancer: primary prevention begins with hpv vaccination of girls aged 9-14 years (before they become sexually active). Avoid smoking or tobacco in any form. Safe sex practices like use of condoms. Avoid multiple sexual partners. Prolapse of the uterus is the descent of the uterus into or outside the vagina. It happens due to weak pelvic muscles and ligaments, which can result in problems during urination and defecation. The causes and risk factors for the weakening of pelvic muscles and ligaments are: 1. Trauma during childbirth (delivery), 2. Multiple pregnancies, 3. Smoking, 4. Old age, 5. Increased abdomen pressure condition (chronic cough, constipation). However, it can be managed conservatively (with pessaries or pelvic floor training) or with surgeries. Symptoms of uterine prolapse can include; a sensation of heaviness or pulling in the pelvis. Vaginal discomfort or pain. A protrusion or bulge felt in the vaginal area. Problems with urination, such as urine leakage or difficulty emptying the bladder. Bowel movement difficulties or constipation. Sexual difficulties or discomfort. Treatment for uterine prolapse depends on the severity of the condition and the individual's symptoms. Non-surgical approaches may include pelvic floor exercises (kegel exercises), pessary insertion (a device placed in the vagina to support the uterus), and lifestyle modifications. In more severe cases or when conservative measures fail, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or remove the prolapsed uterus.

paragraphs.context: Yes, it is normal to have pubic hair. Pubic hair is a natural and normal part of human development, particularly during puberty. The presence of pubic hair is a sign of sexual maturity and is influenced by hormonal changes in the body. The growth of pubic hair varies among individuals in terms of thickness, colour, and distribution. Some people have sparse or fine pubic hair, while others have thicker or coarser hair. The amount and pattern of pubic hair can also differ between males and females. It's important to remember that everyone's body is unique, and there is a wide range of normal variations when it comes to pubic hair. It is a personal and individual characteristic, and there is no standard or "normal" appearance. Ultimately, whether to groom or remove pubic hair is a personal preference and should be based on individual comfort and preferences. Pubic hair removal is a more recent thing but increasingly common grooming practise and shows a great range of variability between different populations. Although carried out by both males and females. It is always a personal choice of a person to remove pubic hair or not. Numerous reasons exist for removing pubic hair, including hygiene, comfort, aesthetic reasons, sex appeal, for oral sex, genitals may look bigger and clean, medical reasons (like a fungal infection, pubic lice infestation, before surgery, etc). A multi-billion-dollar industry has developed around the numerous methods and products available for hair removal. Products and techniques are available include shaving (the most common method is performed with a razor/electric razor), trimmer, waxing, threading/plucking, trimming with scissors, hair removal cream, sugaring (use all-natural paste or gel), dyeing/bleaching, electrolysis, and laser. Pubic hair removal can result in adverse health events, depending on the method used. These complications can include ingrown hair, cuts, injuries, epidermal abrasion, folliculitis, vulvitis, or contact dermatitis. In more serious cases, genital burns can occur from waxing, and severe skin irritation from various products can lead to vaginal irritation or post inflammatory hyperpigmentation. The axillae are uniquely characterised by the presence of hair follicles and sweat glands. These glands secrete a clear, odourless substance, consisting primarily of water and salts. The process of body odour formation in the axillae was found to depend on the biotransformation of these odourless secretions into volatile odoriferous substances by commensal bacteria (corynebacterial or staphylococci) on the skin and hair surfaces. Body odour, in particular axillary odour, is perceived as unpleasant by most cultures worldwide. Moreover, excessive sweating and the resulting unpleasant odour are reported to adversely affect self-confidence and self-esteem in both men and women. Reducing or eliminating body odour is an essential goal of many people's daily personal care routine. Worldwide. paragraphs.context: The menstrual hygiene practises to be followed are: 1. Always use a clean sanitary pad or tampon or menstrual cup to absorb the blood. If a cloth is used, then it should be neat and clean, and prefer cotton cloth. As synthetic cloth may cause skin reactions. 2. Sanitary pad or cloth needs to be changed frequently (at least every four to six hours) to prevent bad odours or infections. 3. If you are using a cloth which, to be reused, it should be washed thoroughly and disinfected by drying in the sun. As sunlight kills the germ. 4. Keep yourself and your genitals clean during the periods. Dont put water soap, or deodorant inside the vagina. 5. Take bath or shower at least once a day. Change the undergarments regularly 6. Wash the genital area from outside with plain water (no soap) after each use of toilet or urination. 7. Keep the area between legs dry, otherwise chaffing or soaring may develop. 8. Eat a healthy diet, iron-rich diet like green leafy vegetables. 9. Always carry an extra sanitary napkin with you, whenever going out. 10. After using the sanitary napkin (pad), wrap it in paper and dispose of in a closed lid dustbin. Never dispose of the sanitary pad in an open place or in the toilet. 11. Exercise can help in relieving the symptoms like premenstrual syndrome, dysmenorrhea and relieve bloating. Exercise also causes the release of serotonin, making one feel much happier. 12. If feeling tired then rest can be taken. Drink adequate water and be hydrated. 13. A heating pad or hot water fomentation can be applied over the abdomen (tummy) to relive the pain or cramps. For cramps and back pain, simple painkillers like paracetamol, mefenamic acid can also be taken. 14. Maintain a calendar/diary, so you are prepared for the next cycle. The steps to using a sanitary pad are: 1. Choose a pad of the appropriate thickness, absorbency, shape, and style. There are two types of pads that can be chosen: with and without wings. "wings" are those sticky little pieces that adhere to your underwear. They keep your pad from lodging to the side and feel like a diaper. In short, unless they irritate your skin or something, they're your friend. "avoid scented pads". 2. Get in position. It'll be easiest if you're sitting down, and your undies are around your knees. Standing is fine, too; you just want everything within arm's reach. 3. Remove any wrappers or boxes from the pad. 4. Fold out the flaps, or wings, and take off the long, centre backing that covers the adhesive in the centre. Expose the adhesive on the wings too. 5. Stick the adhesive part to your panties. You want the pad to be directly beneath your vagina. 6. Wear the panties as usual. Done! "if your pad is itchy or irritating your skin at all, remove it and use a different kind of pad. 7. Make sure to wash your hands before and after changing the pad.

paragraphs.context: Sexually transmitted infections (stis or stds) are infections caused by bacteria, viruses, and parasites transmitted through sexual contact, including vaginal, anal, and oral sex. Some stis may also be spread by skin-to-skin sexual contact or through non-sexual means, such as from mother to child during pregnancy and childbirth. There are more than 30 known bacteria, viruses, and parasites that cause stis. Eight of these pathogens are linked to the greatest incidence of sexually transmitted disease. Of these, four are currently curable: syphilis, gonorrhoea, chlamydia and trichomoniasis. The other four are incurable viral infections: hepatitis b, herpes simplex virus (hsv), hiv and human papillomavirus (hpv). There are eight common infections. Out of which 4 are currently curable: syphilis, gonorrhoea, chlamydia and trichomoniasis. However, the other 4 are viral infections and are incurable: hepatitis b, herpes simplex virus (hsv), human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), and human papillomavirus (hpv). Safe and highly effective vaccines are available for 2 stis: hepatitis b and hpv. Hpv causes cervical cancer in females and penile cancer in males. Symptoms may vary according to gender, severity, and type of stds: std in males: pus/discharge from the penis ulcer, the penis or scrotum pain or burning sensation on urination and swollen or painful testis. Std in females: pus/white, smelly discharge from the vagina, itching or ulcers around the vagina and pain or burning sensation on urination. Any person who indulges in sexual activity is at risk. One person can get multiple stds at the same time. People at higher risk are 1. Who has multiple sexual partners 2. Who has sex with commercial sex workers (prostitutes or sex workers) 3. Homosexual males (as anal sex has a higher risk of hiv transmission compared to vaginal sex). 4. Those who dont follow safe sex practises. The only guaranteed way to avoid or prevent stds is to abstain from sexual activity. The other ways are as follows: (i) avoid sex with unknown partners or multiple partners. (ii) always use condoms during coitus. (iii) in case of doubt, go to a qualified doctor for early detection and treatment (iv) get vaccinated against hepatitis b and hpv. The human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) is a virus that targets the immune system and weakens the bodys defence systems against infections and some types of cancer. The most advanced stage of hiv infection is acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids), which can take from 2 to 15 years to develop, depending on the individual. Aids is defined by the development of certain cancers, infections, or other severe clinical manifestations. There is currently no cure or vaccine for hiv or aids. However, effective antiretroviral (arv) drugs can control the virus and help prevent transmission so that people with hiv, and those at substantial risk, can enjoy healthy, long, and productive lives.

paragraphs.context: Chromosomes decide whether the baby will be a girl or a boy. Women have only one type of chromosome which is x chromosome in the ovum. However, men have two types of chromosomes which are x and y chromosomes. So, if a sperm with an x chromosome fertilises the egg (which has x chromosomes), the baby will be a girl. If a sperm with the y chromosome fertilises the egg, the baby will be a boy". No one can control or decide which sperm will meet the x chromosome of the female ovum. Twins are two babies born in a single pregnancy. They could be identical (lookalikes) or non-identical twins. The identical twins are formed through the division of one fertilised ovum or egg (zygote) into two; thats why they are scientifically also called "monozygotic twins". Non-identical twins are formed due to the fertilisation of two separate ovum or eggs with two sperm; they are also called zygotic twins (fraternal twins). A girl who has started having her periods can become pregnant if semen enters her vagina. No, kissing doesn't lead to creating babies. No, a girl can't become pregnant if semen is ejaculated outside the vagina (nearby the vulva or groin), unless semen (which contains sperm) is ejaculated inside the vagina. However, pre-ejaculatory secretions from the penis, which are released during sexual intercourse for lubrication, may contain some sperm, which can lead to pregnancy. Therefore, it is always advised to use some form of contraception. No, a woman cannot become pregnant if there is no vaginal penetration by the penis. A woman who has been having regular periods stops having them when she is pregnant. So, if a woman who has sex does not get her period on time, it might be a sign that she is pregnant. To be sure that she is pregnant, she needs to have a pregnancy test, as periods can also stop because of illness or tension. Secondly, late signs of pregnancy were breasts becoming enlarged, nipples becoming darker, increased vaginal discharge, feeling the movement of a baby (usually starts around the 5th month) and enlarged abdomen. Ultrasound (usg) confirmatory test detection of hcg in maternal serum or urine can be done as early as 8-11 days of conception.

paragraphs.context: Advice to be followed during pregnancy: 1. The diet should be light, nutritious, easily digestible, rich in protein, minerals, and vitamins. 2. Folic supplements (0.4 mg/day) need to be started as soon as possible (can be started before pregnancy) until the 12th week of pregnancy. It is given to prevent neural tube defects (ntds). 3. Iron tablets need to be started from 4th month onwards up to 6 months postpartum (post delivery). It can be taken with lemon juice, as vitamin c increases the absorption of iron. 4. Try to eat a diet rich in iron such as green leafy vegetables, eggs, meat, and beans. 5. A pregnant woman needs to take 8 hours of sleep in night & 2 hours of sleep in the day (post lunch, in left lateral position). 6. A pregnant woman can travel, but prolonged sitting is avoided. Advised to take a break after every 2 hours (walk and move in between a prolonged journey). In cars, the seat belt should be under the abdomen. Generally, the rail route is preferred. 7. Aircraft travel is safe up to 36 weeks only. In multiple pregnancy, it is safe up to 34 weeks. 8. Avoid smoking and alcohol. Reduce the intake of tea and coffee. 9. Maintain good hygiene (oral, dental, hand, and genitalia). 10. For back pain, diclofenac gel or paracetamol tablet and hot water fomentation can be used. 11. Constipation is common, so it is advised to have lot of fluids and fibres in the diet. E. G. - salads, vegetables, fruits. 12. Vigorous exercise, sitting on the ground, and weight loss need to be avoided. However, evening walks or mild upper limb exercises can be done. 13. Dont miss any meal, always carry some food while travelling or meeting. 14. Take small meals, but frequently. 15. Consult your doctor before taking any medications and keep all the health records safe. Neural tube defects (ntds) are a group of birth defects in which an opening in the spine or cranium remains from early in human development. There are several types of neural tube defects, including spina bifida, anencephaly, encephalocele and iniencephaly. According to cdc, neural tube defects are severe birth defects of the brain and spine. They urge all women of reproductive age to get 400 micrograms (mcg) of folic acid every day, in addition to consuming food with folate from a varied diet, to help prevent neural tube defects. Postpartum refers to the period immediately after childbirth and lasts for up to six months. Thats the amount of time that it takes a womans body to return to a pre-pregnancy state. During this period, women may experience physical and emotional changes that can be challenging. It is important for women to take care of their physical and mental health during this time.

paragraphs.context: Risk factors for hiv behaviours and conditions that put individuals at greater risk of contracting hiv include: 1. Having unprotected anal or vaginal sex; 2. Multiple sexual partners or sex with sex workers; 3. Sharing contaminated needles, syringes and other injecting equipment and drug solutions when injecting; 4. Receiving unsafe injections, blood transfusions, tissue transplantation, medical procedures that involve unsterile cutting or piercing; and 5. Experiencing accidental needle stick injuries, including among health workers. The symptoms of hiv vary depending on the stage of infection. Though people living with hiv tend to be most infectious in the first few months, many are unaware of their status until later stages. The symptoms may be: 1. Fever for more than 3 weeks, 2. Cough or diarrhoea lasting more than 3 weeks which if dont get treated with routine a treatment 3. Weightless despite a good diet 4. Extreme weakness 5. Small multiples swellings in the neck, armpits, or groyne 6. Reddish rash on skin or white patches on mouth. Without treatment, they could also develop severe illnesses such as tuberculosis, cryptococcal meningitis, severe bacterial infections, and cancers such as lymphomas and kaposi's sarcoma. Hiv can be transmitted via the exchange of a variety of body fluids from infected individuals, such as blood, breast milk, semen, and vaginal secretions. Individuals cannot become infected through ordinary day-to-day contacts such as kissing, hugging, shaking hands, or sharing personal objects, food, or water. 5 the major routes of hiv transmission are: 1. Unprotected sexual intercourse with an hiv infected person; 2. Getting transfusion of hiv infected blood; 3. Contaminated syringes and needles; 4. Piercing of ears, nose or tattooing with contaminated instruments; 5. May spread from hiv positive mother to her baby. Hiv doesnt spread via the following modes or methods: 1. Dont spread by hugging; 2. Dont spread by shaking hands; 3. Dont spread by kissing on the cheek or forehead; 4. Dont spread by coughing or sneezing; 5. Dont spread by insect bites or mosquitoes; 6. Dont spread by sharing a towel, mobile, transport vehicle, toilets, or swimming pool; 7. Dont spread by sharing food or crockery. The concentration of hiv virus in saliva, tears, urine, and sweat is very low. Therefore, kissing on the cheek, forehead, or hand wont spread hiv. If a person is having an open-mouth kiss and has an oral ulcer or bleeding gums, then there are certain chances of hiv transmission. Some potential sources of hiv transmission are sharing razors, blades, and toothbrushes. Prevention of hiv: 1. Correct and consistent use of male condoms during vaginal or anal penetration can protect against the spread of sexually transmitted infections, including hiv; 2. A mutually faithful sexual relationship with only one partner; 3. Never reuse any needles or syringes. 4. Be careful with any transfusions, piercings, or cuts. Evidence shows that male condoms have an 85% or greater protective effect against hiv and other sexually transmitted infections (stis).

paragraphs.context: Hernia is the bulging out of the abdomen's contents through a small defect in the muscle or tissue. It could occur in the abdomen or in the groin (inguinal). A groyne hernia is more common in males. It could be present since birth (congenital) or after any abdominal surgery (incisional). The risk factors are old age, obesity, collagen vascular disorder, illness increasing the abdomen pressure (chronic constipation or cough), and weightlifting. People with hernia complaints of a bulging mass in the abdomen or in the groin (e. G. , swelling in the scrotum) with dull or dragging pain. They are reducible in size (by manual manipulation or by lying down) in the initial stages. In the later stage (strangulation of the content), it can become irreducible with severe pain and may need emergency surgery. Medicines don't play any role in hernia treatment. Hernias need to be surgically operated on for treatment. Hydrocele is a swelling in the scrotum (around the testes) due to the accumulation of fluid. It could be due to infections or congenital defects, which are associated with groin hernias, trauma, and tumours. Treatment depends on the age and cause of the hydrocele. Hydroceles can develop in males of all ages, from newborns to adults. In infants, hydroceles often resolve on their own within the first year of life. However, in older boys and men, hydroceles may persist and require medical intervention. The main symptom of a hydrocele is the enlargement of the scrotum, which may appear swollen or filled with fluid. The size of the hydrocele can vary, ranging from small and barely noticeable to large and causing discomfort. Hydroceles are usually painless, but they may cause some discomfort or a heavy feeling in the scrotum. In infants, hydroceles often resolve without treatment. However, if a hydrocele persists or causes discomfort in older individuals, medical intervention may be necessary. Treatment options for hydroceles include watchful waiting, aspiration (draining of the fluid with a needle), or surgical repair (hydrocelectomy) to remove or correct the underlying cause of the hydrocele.

paragraphs.context: Lgbt stands for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer. Here are the meanings of these words: lesbian: a woman is attracted to another woman. (homosexual woman). Gay: commonly term gay is used to describe homosexual man. Bisexual: people who have sexual or romantic feelings for both men and women. Transgender: transgender is an umbrella term that includes all those that sit outside the realm of traditional ideas of gender, which includes trans men, trans women, people who go through gender reassignment, people who choose not to, people who do not wish to identify as male or female, and people who wish to identify as both. Queer: queer is an umbrella term for people who are not heterosexual and/or do not conform to gender norms. For example, transgender people, bisexual people, and homosexual people. Intersex: intersex is a term that is used for people whose biological sex cannot be clearly classified as either male or female, they have ambiguous genitalia. It is important that intersex individuals get to determine their own sex and gender, just like everyone else. Sexuality is not just based on the body or the body parts alone. Sexuality is experienced and expressed in thoughts, fantasies, desires, beliefs, attitudes, values, behaviours, practises, roles, and relationships. Biological sex: it refers to the biological characteristics that define humans as female or male. For example, based on the genitalia a boy (male) has a penis and a girl (female) have a vagina. It is influenced by biological factors (genes, hormones) only. Sexuality (gender): it is a central aspect of being human throughout life and encompasses sex, gender identities and roles, sexual orientation, eroticism, pleasure, intimacy, and reproduction. It can be other than male and female also. It can be influenced by the interaction of biological and external factors (psychological, social, economic, political, cultural, ethical, legal, historical, religious, and spiritual factors). Sexuality (gender identity) is persons internal, deeply felt sense of being male, female, other, or in between. Everyone has a gender identity. Sexual orientation: it refers to whether a person is sexually attracted (aroused) to a person of the same sex or different sex or gender. One does not have to be sexually active to have a sexual orientation. It also refers as established sexual preference. Sexual behaviour: it is the is the way humans experience and express their sexuality. It also refers as sexual action. Sexual orientation develops as you grow and experience new things. Mothers with postpartum depression experience feelings of extreme sadness, anxiety, and exhaustion that may make it difficult for them to complete daily care activities for themselves or for others. Postpartum depression does not have a single cause but is likely results from a combination of physical and emotional factors. Only a health care provider can diagnose a woman with postpartum depression, as symptoms of this condition are broad and may vary between women. The condition, which occurs in nearly 15 percent of births, may begin shortly before or any time after childbirth, but commonly begins between a week and a month after delivery. Because of the severity of the symptoms, postpartum depression usually requires treatment, but it can be treated with counselling and medications. Please don't hesitate to consult with the doctor. Abortion is generally illegal in malaysia, except in specific circumstances. The relevant law governing abortion in malaysia is the penal code, under sections 312 to 316. According to these sections, abortion is a criminal offence unless it is necessary to save the life of the pregnant woman or if it is performed with the intention of preserving the woman's physical or mental health. In cases where an abortion is deemed necessary, it must be performed by a registered medical practitioner in a government-approved facility. Cyberbullying involves posting or sending electronic messages (sometimes anonymously), including text, pictures, or videos, aimed at harassing, threatening, or spreading rumours and sexual remarks about another person via a variety of digital platforms such as online social networks, chat rooms, blogs, instant messaging, and text messaging. Protection of children from sexual offences (pocso) act was introduced in 2012, which it was enacted with the aim of protecting children below the age of 18. It provides a robust legal framework for the protection of children from offences of sexual assault, sexual harassment, and pornography, it also criminalises acts of immodesty against children too. It criminalises even watching or collection of pornographic content involving children. The framing of the act seeks to put children first by making it easy to use by including mechanisms for child-friendly reporting, recording of evidence, investigation, and speedy trial of offences through designated special courts. The act also criminalises consensual sexual intercourse between two people below the age of 18. Age for consent for sexual intercourse in 18 years of age. Under this act, if any girl under 18 is seeking abortion the service provider is compelled to register a complaint of sexual assault with the police. Punishment under pocso ranges from 3 years imprisonment to life imprisonment with or without fine. Appropriate age of marriage in malaysia: civil marriages: the legal age of marriage for non-muslims in malaysia is governed by the law reform (marriage and divorce) act 1976. According to this act, the minimum age for marriage is 18 for both males and females. However, individuals who are 16 or 17 years old may be allowed to marry with the consent of their parents or guardians and the permission of the chief minister of the state they reside in. Islamic marriages: for muslims in malaysia, the legal age of marriage is determined by islamic family law, which falls under the jurisdiction of the shariah courts. The islamic family law (federal territories) act 1984 sets the minimum age of marriage for muslims as 18 for males and 16 for females. paragraphs.context: Depression is due to multiple factors resulting from complex mechanisms; there can be no single identifiable cause. However, there is conclusive evidence to reveal that several biological (genetic), social, economic, cultural, and environmental factors contribute to depression. Common causes are endogenous (biological), stress, disease, old age, love failure, post-delivery, poverty, social conflicts, etc. Depression can range from mild to severe based on its symptoms. Following are the signs and symptoms of depression: 1. Frequent sadness, tearfulness, and crying 2. Decreased interest in activities or inability to enjoy formerly favourite activities 3. Hopelessness 4. Persistent boredom, low energy 5. Social isolation, poor communication 6. Extreme sensitivity to rejection or failure 7. Increased irritability, anger, or hostility 8. Difficulty with relationships 9. Frequent complaints of physical illness, such as headaches or stomach-aches 10. Frequent absences from school or poor performance in school 11. Poor concentration 12. Feeling overwhelmed easily or often. 13. A major change in eating and/or sleeping patterns 14. Talk of or efforts to run away from home 15. Thoughts or expressions of suicide or self-destructive behaviour. Treatment of depression: there are various forms of treatment available, from counselling to medications. Depression is largely preventable and treatable. Depression is not a sign of weakness. Please feel free to seek medical and to talk about it to your friends. Stress management skills for young people and adults: 1. Talk about problems with other trusted people like friends, parents, teachers, etc. 2. Take deep breaths, accompanied by thinking or saying aloud, "i can handle this". 3. Perform progressive muscle relaxation, which involves repeatedly tensing and relaxing large muscles of the body. You can count from 10 to 1 (reverse counting). 4. Set small goals and break tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. 5. Exercise and eat regular meals. Involve in outdoor sports and be physically active. 6. Get proper sleep, at least 6-7 hours per day. 7. Break the habit of relying on caffeine or energy drinks to get through the day. 8. Focus on what you can control (your reactions, your actions) and let go of what you cannot (other peoples opinions and expectations). 9. Work through worst-case scenarios until they seem amusing or absurd 10. Lower unrealistic expectations. 11. Schedule breaks and enjoyable activities. 12. Accept yourself as you are; identify your unique strengths and build on them. 13. Give up on the idea of perfection, both in yourself and in others.

paragraphs.context: Infatuation refers to an intense and often short-lived emotional or romantic attraction towards someone. It is characterized by an intense passion, obsession, and idealization of the person, often accompanied by a heightened sense of excitement and euphoria. Infatuation is typically based on superficial qualities or idealized perceptions of the individual, and it often lacks a deep understanding of their true character or compatibility. Infatuation is primarily driven by intense emotions and physical attraction, and it may fade over time or evolve into a more mature and lasting form of love, or it may dissipate without developing into a long-term relationship. Lust refers to a strong and often overwhelming desire for sexual gratification or physical pleasure. It is primarily driven by intense sexual attraction or arousal, and it tends to be focused on the physical aspects of a person rather than their emotional or intellectual qualities. Lust is characterized by a strong and immediate sexual appetite, often detached from emotional connection or long-term commitment. It is a powerful and instinctual force, but it is transient and may fade once the sexual desire is fulfilled or if other aspects of a deeper connection are absent. Lust alone does not encompass the emotional intimacy and deeper emotional connection found in genuine love or healthy relationships. The differences between infatuation and love are infatuation is short-lived and based on superficial qualities, while love endures and encompasses deeper emotional connection. Infatuation is focused on physical attraction, while love includes care, compassion, and selflessness. Infatuation fluctuates in emotions, while love provides stability and understanding. Infatuation is self-centred, while love prioritizes the well-being of the other person. Infatuation is more present-focused, while love involves a long-term perspective. Infatuation lacks depth of connection, while love involves deep emotional and intellectual understanding. Infatuation may struggle with acceptance, while love allows for growth and acceptance of the other person. Infatuation and lust share some similarities, but they are not the same. While both involve intense feelings and desires, there are key differences between them which were infatuation involves intense emotional attraction, while lust is primarily driven by intense sexual desire. Infatuation can include emotional connection, while lust is focused on physical attraction. Infatuation may fade over time, while lust can be transient. Infatuation has the potential to evolve into deeper love, while lust may not lead to a long-term relationship. Infatuation is based on idealized perceptions, while lust is driven by immediate sexual gratification.

paragraphs.context: A relationship is a connection between people based on mutual interactions and emotions. It involves shared experiences, trust, and communication. It can be romantic, familial, friendly, or professional. They require effort, compromise, and understanding to thrive. Healthy relationships bring joy, support, and a sense of belonging. Relationships can be short-lived or long-lasting. Each relationship is unique, with its own dynamics and expectations. They play a crucial role in our emotional well-being and happiness. Love is a deep and intense emotion. It involves affection, care, and attachment. It can be romantic, familial, or platonic. It brings joy, happiness, and fulfilment. Love requires commitment, understanding, and support. It can be expressed through actions and words. Love is a transformative force in relationships. It can also involve vulnerability and challenges. Love is a personal and subjective experience. It contributes to our well-being and happiness. The differences between relationship and love where love is an intense emotion, while a relationship is the connection or bond between people. Love is the foundation of a relationship, providing the emotional basis for the connection. A relationship encompasses the broader dynamics, interactions, and shared experiences between individuals. Love can exist without a formal relationship, but a relationship typically involves mutual love and commitment. Love is a feeling, while a relationship is the practical manifestation of that feeling in the form of shared experiences and interactions. Love is internal, while a relationship is external and observable by others. Love can exist in various forms, but a relationship implies a more defined connection between individuals. Love is the emotional glue that holds a relationship together, fostering intimacy and connection. A romantic relationship is a deep and intimate connection between two individuals based on love, attraction, and mutual affection. It involves emotional and physical intimacy, as well as romantic and sexual feelings. Romantic relationships often include shared experiences, support, and a desire for a long-term partnership. They require effort, communication, and commitment to nurture and maintain. Romantic relationships can bring joy, companionship, and a sense of fulfilment when built on trust, respect, and mutual understanding.

paragraphs.context: There are lots of techniques to deal with peer pressure. 1. First, one must know what is good and bad for him; if he is unaware, he must talk to his parents or a responsible adult about it. 2. You must understand that peer-pressure is a long term or lifelong thing. You must take a stand, deal with it, and speak about it. Be assertive by speaking out when someone is being bullied or pressured into making a sexual decision that they dont want to make. 3. Be smart and patient, never act in the heat of the moment. Plan for it and try to find ways to deal with it in a subtle and smart way. 4. The best is to discuss with the people you trust, like your parents, teachers, or any responsible adults. They may be able to give you better ways or tricks to get away with it. The process of making decisions about sexual behaviour includes consideration of all positive and negative potential consequences. Decisions about sexual behaviour can affect peoples health, future, and life plans. There are factors that can make it difficult to make rational decisions about sexual behaviour like the range of emotions, alcohol and drugs, poverty, gender inequality, and violence. Decision-making is a skill that can be learned and practiced. Things a parent or guardian should do to have a good understanding of their child's sexual and reproductive health: 1. Never deny or ignore the questions of kids; always answer them with truth and logic. Kids are smart and intelligent. Dont underestimate them. 2. Never lie to a kid, as it leads to a loss of trust and faith. 3. Get their trust. So, in case of trouble or problems, they should come first to you with ease. 4. Never simply say dont do it" or that is bad. Instead, always explain the real scientific reason for not doing so. 5. Always be careful with the words you use in front of kids. They listen, observe, and remember everything. They may learn bad things or bad words from you. 6. Never cross dress them when they are young. Example: never dress a boy as a girl, this may later impact him psychologically. 7. Never undress them in front of outsiders or unknown people. Give them full privacy and respect. 8. paragraphs.context: Breast size can vary significantly among females. There is a wide range of breast sizes and shapes, influenced by factors such as genetics, hormones, body composition, and overall health. Here are some general descriptions of breast sizes: small breasts: small breasts are typically characterized by a petite size with minimal breast tissue. They may have a flatter appearance and less projection from the chest wall. Average or medium-sized breasts: this is a common breast size range that varies depending on individual proportions. Average-sized breasts have a moderate amount of breast tissue and may have a rounded shape with moderate projection. Large breasts: large breasts have a significant amount of breast tissue and may have a fuller, rounder appearance. They typically project further from the chest wall and may require additional support. It's important to note that breast size is not an indicator of femininity or beauty, and every person's breasts are unique. There is no "standard" or "ideal" breast size, as beauty and attractiveness come in diverse forms. It's essential to focus on overall health and well-being rather than solely on breast size. If you have concerns about your breast size or any other aspect of your breasts, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare provider for personalized guidance and support. Women wear bras or brassieres to support their breasts. As a girls breasts grow, she may need to get a different sized bra every couple of years, till her breasts have stopped growing. There is nothing unusual about this. Everyone grows at a different pace. A female needs to wear a bra when her breasts have grown enough to jiggle or bounce when she runs. A female feels more comfortable wearing a bra especially if she goes for jogging or any sport. There are various styles and sizes of bra available. The right bra is one that supports the breasts like a second skin. A female should wear a bra that is neither too tight nor too loose and preferably a cotton one. A woman should take off the bra at night to allow for proper blood circulation and so that she can breathe comfortably while sleeping. To determine if the bra you are wearing is suitable: band: the band should fit snugly around your torso without digging in or riding up. Cups: the cups should fully enclose your breasts without spillage or gaps. Underwire: if present, the underwire should rest against your rib cage without poking or pinching. Shoulder straps: they should stay in place without digging into your shoulders or sliding off. Overall comfort: the bra should feel comfortable to wear without causing pain or irritation.

During the teen years, the body is just getting used to these new sensations, and sometimes you might find yourself reacting like this quite suddenly. paragraphs.context: According to the malaysian law, sexual intercourse by inserting the penis into the mouth of another person is categorized as sodomy. The punishment for sodomy is imprisonment for a term which may extend to 20 years and whipping. Things a rape victim can do: 1. Dont be scared, directly file a police complaint, or tell it to your parent or someone (responsible adult) whom you trust. 2. Before the collection of medical evidence by a forensic team (police) - dont take bath, dont change clothes, dont wash the vagina or anus or mouth, dont cut nails. As they contain certain forensic evidence which may get destroyed. 3. Dont fear any call threat or blackmail. Because once you get scared, then it will boost the confidence of the perpetrator and he may repeat the assault again. 4. If you dont feel like going to the police station on the same day. Take your time and then file a written or online complaint. 5. Your identity will not be revealed in public or media in any form. As revealing the identity of the rape victim is a punishable crime under the law. 6. If needed then avail the government facilities for counselling, contraception, legal and social matters. Remember that children dont make up stories about sexual abuse. Listen to their every word carefully and take them seriously. Myths and facts about sexual abuse: myths: 1. Only girls are vulnerable to child abuse; 2. Abusers are mostly strangers; 3. Child abuse is only in the form of contact abuse; 4. Children with disabilities arent abused; 5. Children will always complain about the abuse; 6. Playing doctor-doctor is a form of abuse; 7. Child sexual abuse most often occurs in lower-class families; 8. Abused children forget about their abuse when they become adults. It's better to forget about the abuse anyway. Facts: 1. Both boys and girls are vulnerable to sexual abuse; 2. It is seen that mostly abusers is someone who knows or is related to the children they abuse; 3. It could be in form of non-contact also like forced to see or listen to inappropriate videos or talks, sending vulgar messages, etc. ; 4. Children with disability are more vulnerable as they cant move away from the abuser and may not be able to report it; 5. Children who are sexually abused may not tell others for many reasons and even deny the abuse. As they may lack vocabulary to describe or scared or may feel shame/blamed, etc. ; 6. Name of the game is not the type of sexual abuse. Sexual abuse must do more with activities and exertion of the power; 7. Child sexual abuse occurs in all socioeconomic classes. Education and social class are no guarantees against abuse. They all share the same profile and characteristics; 8. Everyone react in a different way. paragraphs.context: With the help of medicine, menstrual periods can be delayed by up to 1-2 weeks. For this, you need to consult your doctor. Frequent use of medications or use of medications for a longer duration can result in side effects and affect hormone regulation. Vaginal douching is the process of intravaginal cleansing with a liquid solution or water. Some women do it after menstruation or after sex. Douching can change the necessary balance of vaginal flora (good bacteria live in the vagina) and the natural acidic environment in a healthy vagina. Douching can lead to bacterial vaginosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (pid), problems during pregnancy (ectopic pregnancy, preterm), and other problems. The vagina cleans itself. Therefore, it is advised not to douche. Menstruations usually stop by the age of 50 (called menopause). In some cases, they may stop quite early or late. The age of menopause may depend on genetics and lifestyle (smoking, obesity, physical activity, and diet). "menopausal transition or perimenopause is the time before the menopause (approx. 40 to 50 years of age). In this period, there are hormonal and emotional changes. Dating apps are online platforms or mobile applications that allow people to connect and interact with others who are interested in romantic or sexual relationships. Users create profiles, browse through potential matches, and communicate with others through messaging within the app. These apps provide a convenient and accessible way to meet new people and explore potential connections. Dating violence also includes stalking. In any form of dating violence, a person should seek for help from parents/guardians, friends or authority. If needed, you can always take help of police and legal system. 1. Emotional violence is when one partner threatens the other or harms his or her sense of self-worth or self-esteem. Emotional violence includes things like calling names, behaving in a controlling or jealous way, monitoring the other person constantly, shaming, or bullying. Emotional violence also happens when someone keeps the other away from friends and family. 2. Physical violence is when someone pinches, hits, shoves, slaps, punches, or kicks their partner. 3. Stalking is any form of repeated and unwanted contact that makes a person feel unsafe.

paragraphs.context: Sexual abuse is a term used to describe any sexual activity that is unwanted or carried out without consent. It may include touching and non-touching activity. Touching activity includes kissing, hugging, fondling, oral sex, or penetration. Non-touching activity includes exposure to sexual acts or pornography. Child sexual abuse is any interaction between a child and an adult (or another child) in which the child is used for the sexual stimulation of the perpetrator or an observer. Sexual abuse can include both touching and non-touching behaviours. Non-touching behaviours can include voyeurism (trying to look at a childs naked body), exhibitionism, or exposing the child to pornography. Children of all ages, races, ethnicities, and economic backgrounds may experience sexual abuse. Child sexual abuse can include both touching and non-touching behaviours. Touching activities include touching a childs genitalia (private parts) for sexual pleasure. Making a child touch someones genitals, play a sexual game, or have sex. Putting any object or any body part (finger, tongue, etc. ) inside the vagina or mouth, or anus for sexual pleasure. Non-touching activities include deliberately exposing an adults genitals to a child, inappropriately watching undress or while using the bathroom, showing pornography to a child, photographing a child in sexual poses, encouraging a child to watch sexual acts, and showing or flashing genitals to a child. Under malaysian law, rape is defined as sexual intercourse with a woman without her consent or against her will. A man who commits rape shall be punished for a term which may extend to 20 years, and shall also be liable to whipping, if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under any of the following circumstances: (g) with or without her consent, when she is under 16 years of age. Sex with a girl below 16 years of age is statutory rape, regardless of whether she consents to it or not. 1. Rape: rape is defined under section 375 of the penal code. It refers to non-consensual sexual intercourse with a person without their consent. The offense is gender-neutral, meaning it can be committed against both men and women. 2. Sexual assault: while the term "sexual assault" is not specifically defined in the malaysian penal code, it generally refers to any non-consensual sexual act or contact that does not involve penetration. It can include various forms of unwanted sexual touching, groping, or other acts of a sexual nature without the individual's consent. 3. Unlawful sexual connection: under section 377b of the penal code, unlawful sexual connection refers to any act of penetration (including oral or anal penetration) without the consent of the person involved. This provision covers non-consensual sexual acts that fall short of the legal definition of rape. 4. Sexual abuse: sexual abuse encompasses a broad range of non-consensual sexual acts, including acts of indecent assault, molestation, or any other form of sexual misconduct. While the term "sexual abuse" may not be specifically defined in the penal code, it can encompass various forms of unwanted sexual contact or behaviour that violates a person's boundaries.

Then pull out, while holding the condom in place. Withdrawal the penis, while the penis is still erect. Take off the condom without spilling semen on the vagina. Step 6. Carefully remove the condom, tie a knot at the open end of the condom, cover it in a wrapper or paper, and throw it in the trash. Never reuse them.
