Also, the vagina doesnt have any taste buds. Never use any plastic sheet or anything except condoms, as they may break or slip easily, causing pregnancy. Also, introducing any unsterile thing into the vagina can cause infections, and the irregular surfaces can cause trauma or injury. Condoms are easily available at most pharmacies and general shops. paragraphs.context: A break-up is the ending of a romantic relationship, often due to incompatibility, differences in values, or conflicts. It can be emotionally challenging, involving emotions like sadness, anger, confusion, or relief. Communication is crucial during a break-up, and individuals may choose to take time for self-reflection, self-care, and personal growth. Seeking support from friends, family, or counsellors can help navigate the emotional aftermath. Over time, individuals may heal and move forward, opening themselves up to new possibilities and future relationships. Break-ups happen due to reasons such as incompatibility, loss of connection, lack of communication or trust, unresolved issues or conflicts, different life paths, and in cases of abuse or toxicity. They occur when the relationship is no longer fulfilling, healthy, or aligned with the individuals' needs and goals. Rejection refers to the act of refusing or dismissing someone or something. It involves denying acceptance, approval, or participation. Rejection can evoke feelings of disappointment, hurt, or exclusion. It is a normal part of life and can occur in various contexts, such as relationships, job applications, or social situations. Dealing with rejection requires resilience, self-reflection, and the understanding that it does not define one's worth or potential for future success. Everyone has a different coping mechanism. If a method works for somebody, that doesnt mean it may work for you. Here are some ways to deal with it - 1. Try to deal with it maturely. A person is very vulnerable to addiction, depression, suicide, etc. We must understand that these things are temporary. You must think about your career, parents, and friends. Appreciate the things what you currently have in life. Dont take any steps in the heat of the moment. 2. Talk about it with friends or family, a support is needed. 3. Let your emotions - cry, sob, write, shout etc. Crying is a normal emotion. 4. Indulge in some activities to divert your attention - go out for a movie, party, swimming, sports, dancing, read a book, etc. 5. You can also get involved in spirituality or meditation. 6. Try to look at the positive side of it and every failure is new learning. 7. If needed then, dont be scared to take professional help. Remember that time is the best healer, with time everything heals. Love is not about gaining always, its also about letting the person go. Somethings are not in your control.

paragraphs.context: The breasts are the mammary glands located on the chest of females and, to a lesser extent, males. They are a prominent part of the female reproductive system and play a role in milk production for breastfeeding. Breasts are composed of glandular tissue, fat, and connective tissue, and their size, shape, and appearance can vary from person to person. Breasts typically consist of a nipple, areola (the pigmented area surrounding the nipple), and breast tissue that extends outward from the chest wall. The breast tissue contains milk ducts and lobules, which produce and transport milk during lactation. Hormonal changes during puberty, menstrual cycles, pregnancy, and menopause can affect the size and sensitivity of breasts. Apart from their biological function, breasts can also have cultural, aesthetic, and emotional significance for individuals. Regular breast self-examination and routine breast health screenings are important for early detection of any abnormalities or changes in breast tissue. If you have concerns about your breast health, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare provider. Lactation is the natural process of producing and secreting milk from the breasts, primarily occurring in females after childbirth to nourish and provide essential nutrients to the newborn. Breasts start producing milk (called lactation) after the delivery of the baby. Newborn babies are fed exclusively only on breast milk for the first 6 months of life. Milk production is a highly coordinated system between the nervous system and endocrine system of the body. Amount of milk production also depends on the sucking of breast nipple the baby, nutritional status of the mother, physical activity, and healthy lifestyle. Normally breasts secrete from 450ml to 800ml of milk after pregnancy. If a woman who never got pregnant starts women start lactating, then she must consult a doctor for further evaluation of the cause. It is advised to avoid losing weight rapidly after pregnancy, as it can interfere with lactation. It is relatively common for some females to experience a delay or difficulty in milk production after giving birth, but it is not considered the norm. With proper support and breastfeeding techniques, milk production typically starts within a few days after childbirth. However, in rare cases, some females may have challenges in producing sufficient milk supply despite their efforts. Seeking guidance from healthcare professionals or lactation consultants is important in such situations. It's important to remember that there are alternative feeding options available to ensure the baby receives proper nutrition if breastfeeding is not possible.

paragraphs.context: When a boy is sexually excited, his penis becomes hard and stands up. This is known as an erection or a hard-on and occurs because of increased blood flow to the penis. This is a normal phenomenon. Erections sometimes occur on their own, without any sexual stimulus. During sleep, there is some change in the nervous system of the body, causing erection of the penis in the morning or in sleep. This is perfectly natural and normal. It does not mean that a man is over-sexed. Semen is a white, thick liquid containing sperms mixed with the secretions of the epididymis and prostate. It is made up of sperms, sugar, water, enzymes, and protein. The normal quantity of semen per ejaculation is 1.5 to 4 ml, containing about 20 to 80 million sperms/ml. Emission of the semen during masturbation or during erection is completely normal; there shouldnt be any guilt or bad feelings about it. The production of sperm is a continuous process that doesnt stop. Normal semen colour is white grey in colour. It can have a yellowish tinge sometimes when there is prolonged abstinence (from masturbation or sex), which is due to carotene pigment, and sperm oxidation causes odour. If a person ejaculates frequently (e. G. , too many times in a day), then the colour may be watery (mildly transparent), which is a temporary condition and normal. The colour of semen may change due to fresh blood (red), drugs (pyridium), jaundice (dark yellow), or contamination of semen with urine (e. G. , in bladder neck dysfunction). A person needs to consult a doctor if there is any abnormal semen colour (red, dark yellow, brown, green, etc). "nocturnal emission or nightfall or wet dreams is the spontaneous ejaculation of semen during sleep. Many adolescents get scared when it occurs first. It is a normal physiological process. It occurs after reaching puberty. It doesnt lead to weakness or impotence. No, if a man never had nocturnal emission, it doesnt mean that he has any abnormality. Sometimes women may also get erotic dreams in sleep and some vaginal secretions may be released, which can be compared to a nocturnal emission. It can be seen in rare case of retrograde ejaculation (in which semen comes out with urine just after every orgasm). Research shows that normal people who are very much frightened about the semen loss may also report it, due to the anxiety/depression or sexual dysfunction (as they think semen as extremely precious body element). It is often even called as dhat syndrome. The management includes sex education for the misconception, counselling, relaxation therapy and some anti-anxiety medications (if needed).

paragraphs.context: The hymen is a thin membrane located at the opening of the vagina in females. It is a natural part of the female reproductive anatomy. The hymen can vary in shape, size, and flexibility among individuals. It can be stretched or torn during various activities, including sexual intercourse, physical activities, medical examinations, or even through regular daily activities. Contrary to common misconceptions, the presence, absence, or condition of the hymen does not determine a person's virginity or sexual history. An imperforate hymen is a condition in which the hymen completely covers the opening of the vagina, leaving no opening for menstrual blood to pass through. It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present at birth. The imperforate hymen can obstruct the normal flow of menstrual blood, resulting in symptoms such as abdominal pain, cyclic pain without bleeding, or amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods) once a girl reaches puberty. Treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves a minor surgical procedure called hymenotomy, which creates a small opening in the hymen to allow for the normal passage of menstrual blood. This procedure is usually performed by a healthcare professional and is considered safe and effective. It is important to consult a healthcare provider for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment if an imperforate hymen is suspected.

paragraphs.context: Puberty changes (secondary sexual characters) in girls: 1. Appearance of breast buds (between 8 and 12 years of age), 2. Followed by breast development (between 13-18yrs) 3. Development of pubic hair (between 11-14yr) 4. Growth spurt begins (between average age 10yrs), which adds inches to height and hip circumference 5. Manses begins (average age 12yr, normal age range between 9 and 16yrs) 6. Enlargement of ovaries, uterus, labia, and clitoris; thickening of the endometrium and vaginal mucosa 7. Appearance of underarm hair (between 13-16yrs) 8. Dental changes, which include jaw growth and development of molars 9. Development of body odour and acne. Puberty changes (secondary sexual characters) in boys: 1. Testicular enlargement, beginning as early as 9-12 years of age 2. Appearance of pubic hair (10-15 years. ) 3. Onset of sperm arche, or sperm found in the ejaculate (erection and wet dreams) 4. Scrotal thickness and darkens 5. Lengthening of genitals (11-14 years) 5. Rapid enlargement of the larynx, pharynx, and lungs, which can lead to alterations in vocal quality (i. E. , voice cracking) 6. Changes in physical growth (average age 14), first seen in the hands and feet, followed by the arms and legs, and then the trunk and chest 7. Weight gain and increases in lean body mass and muscle mass (1116 years) 8. Growth of facial and body hair, which may not be completed until the mid-20s 9. Dental changes, which include jaw growth and development of molars 10. Development of body odour and acne. Puberty typically starts for girls between ages 8 and 13, and for boys between ages 9 and 14, and may continue until age 19 or older. Hormones are released by the brain to start puberty. Puberty that begins before age 8 in girls and before age 9 in boys is considered as precocious puberty (early puberty). It could be due to underlying medical conditions in the body. So, consult a doctor as soon as possible.

paragraphs.context: Hiv infection is often diagnosed through rapid diagnostic tests (rdts), which detect the presence or absence of hiv antibodies. Most often, these tests provide same-day test results, which are essential for early treatment and care. Most individuals develop antibodies to hiv within 28 days of infection, and therefore antibodies may not be detectable early, during the so-called window period. This early period of infection represents the time of greatest infectivity; however, hiv transmission can occur during all stages of the infection. Until now, there has been no cure for hiv. Three of the most important rights in the hiv scenario include: right to informed consent: testing for hiv requires the specific and informed consent of the person being tested and for any research and information sharing. ; right to confidentiality: a person has the right to keep information about their hiv status private. Right to confidentiality. However, they can take advantage of the suppression of identity under a pseudonym; right against discrimination: a person has the right to be treated equally as per the fundamental rights covered under the law and constitution. Remember: please dont look at any hiv patient with contempt or any judgement. Treat them normally and affectionately. They deserve to be respected.

paragraphs.context: Nothing much will happen to a male if they take an oral contraceptive pill or emergency pill, but it is advised not to do so. If the sexual intercourse was done in the last 72 hours, then a female can take an emergency contraceptive pill. A married woman can even choose intrauterine copper t (which is effective within 5 days of unprotected sex). If it is more than 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected sexual intercourse, then you can wait for the girls next period (as every sexual intercourse may not lead to pregnancy). If her next period is missed, she may need to undergo a pregnancy test. Therefore, it is always advised to use protection. There is no data available for how long before an emergency pill can be taken. However, mostly, it can be taken just before the intercourse. The least effective are natural methods. Therefore, it is always advised to avoid using natural methods, as there is a high chance of failure. Condoms provide approximately 80% protection against sexually transmitted diseases (stds). Condoms have a high failure rate of 12%, but if they are used properly, the failure rate can be reduced to 3%. They can fail due to slippage, breakage, etc. Dont panic if a condom breaks or slips. You can use emergency contraception, or you can wait for the next menstrual cycle. If there is a delay in the menstrual cycle beyond 1 week, then contact a doctor for further evaluation and management. Dos for condom use: do use a condom every time you have sex. Do put on a condom before having sex. Do read the package and check the expiration date. Do make sure there are no tears or defects. Do store condoms in a cool, dry place. Do use latex or polyurethane condoms. Do use water-based or silicone-based lubricant to prevent breakage. Dont for condom use: dont store condoms in your wallet as heat and friction can damage them. Dont use nonoxynol-9 (a spermicide), as this can cause irritation. Dont use oil-based products like baby oil, lotion, petroleum jelly, or cooking oil because they will cause the condom to break. Dont use more than one condom at a time. It may cause friction and lead to the breakage of the condom dont reuse a condom. Dont wash a condom dont use latex condom if you are allergic to latex

paragraphs.context: 1. The prostate is a gland that makes fluid for semen. This gland also surrounds the urethra at the neck of the urinary bladder. It is a small gland found in males, located just below the bladder and in front of the rectum. It is part of the male reproductive system and plays a role in the production and secretion of seminal fluid, which helps nourish and transport sperm during ejaculation. The prostate gland is roughly the size and shape of a walnut. It surrounds the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the body, and the urethra runs through the middle of the prostate. The prostate gland undergoes changes throughout a man's life, with the most significant growth occurring during puberty. Prostate problems in old age happen due to the increase in age as the size of the prostate increases due to hormones, genes, etc. It is called "benign prostatic hyperplasia (bph). Due to the growth of the prostate, it compresses the urethra (blocks it), which causing symptoms like 1. Increased urinary frequency (urination eight or more times a day); 2. Urinary urgency (the inability to delay urination) 3. Trouble starting a urine stream 4. A weak or interrupted urine stream 5. Dribbling at the end of urination 6. Nocturia (frequent urination during sleep) 7. Urinary retention 8. Urinary incontinence (the accidental loss of urine) 9. Pain after ejaculation or during urination 10. Urine that has an unusual colour or smell 11. A person needs medical help. It can be treated or controlled using medicines or surgery. The myths (misconception) about masculinity or manhood:1. Real men don't show emotions. Its healthy for all individuals to express and process their emotions. 2. Real men are always tough and aggressive. Strength can be shown through empathy, compassion, and emotional intelligence. 3. Real men don't seek help or show vulnerability. Seeking support is a sign of strength and prioritizing mental well-being. 4. Real men are successful and financially dominant. True masculinity is not solely based on external achievements but on qualities like integrity and personal growth. 5. Real men are always interested in sex and should be sexually dominant. Individual preferences and consent should guide sexual relationships. Challenging these myths fosters inclusivity and allows men to embrace their authentic selves.
